background: Adults born preterm at very low birth weight have increased risks for various health conditions, potentially mediated by epigenetic regulation.
hypotheses: There are blood DNAm differences between young adults born preterm at VLBW and term controls.
Some of these differences may be seen in unrelated cohorts of varying ages when investigating birth weight as the exposure.
Some of the differences in DNAm may be related to secondary birth exposures.
major_findings: Sixty-six CpG sites were differentially methylated between VLBW adults and controls in the discovery cohort.
Five CpG sites near GLI2 were hypermethylated in VLBW individuals and associated with lower birth weight in a meta-analysis of four independent cohorts.
These findings suggest an epigenetic signature of preterm birth at VLBW present in adult life.
null_findings: No single CpG site was differentially methylated in all cohorts, even those validated in the meta-analysis.
Exploratory analyses of secondary exposures (gestational age, birth weight SD, SGA) did not reveal consistent findings across all cohorts.
new_open_questions: What are the molecular mechanisms linking preterm birth to later health outcomes?
Do the identified epigenetic differences persist further into adulthood and how do they relate to future cardiovascular risk?
What is the causal relationship between the identified epigenetic changes and the observed health outcomes?
